items.title: How I Built My Personal Developer Portfolio from Scratch
items.author: Vikas Santosh Rathod
items.description:
Hi everyone! I’m Vikas — a full stack developer passionate about building real-world tech solutions and exploring new technologies. Recently, I decided to create my own portfolio website to showcase my projects, skills, and journey. In this blog, I’ll walk you through how I did it, step by step!

🎯 Why I Built a Portfolio

Having a portfolio is super important for developers — especially when you’re applying for jobs or internships. It acts like a digital resume where you can:

  • Showcase your best projects 💻
  • Highlight your tech stack 🛠
  • Share your blogs (like this one!) ✍️
  • Give recruiters a snapshot of who you are 🚀

🔧 Tech Stack I Used

I built my portfolio using:

  • React.js for the frontend
  • Tailwind CSS for styling
  • GitHub Pages for hosting
  • A cool open-source template: developerFolio

🚀 Steps I Followed

1. Cloned the developerFolio template

bashgit clone https://github.com/saadpasta/developerFolio.git

2. Customized the portfolio.js file

I updated it with my:

  • Name
  • Skills
  • GitHub projects
  • Social links

3. Personalized the design

Using Tailwind CSS, I tweaked colors and layout to match my style and make it clean and minimal.

4. Added My Projects

Some of the projects I included:

  • 🖱 Virtual Mouse (Using Python & OpenCV)
  • 🧮 Currency Converter (Using JS & API)
  • 📋 Notes Manager (Using React, Tailwind, Node.js)

5. Deployed it on GitHub Pages

I used the built-in deploy script to publish it:

💡 Lessons I Learned

  • How to configure .env and fetch dynamic data
  • Importance of clean UI/UX
  • Basics of deploying React apps on GitHub Pages
  • Showcasing your personality through your portfolio

📌 Final Thoughts

Creating this portfolio was a fun and rewarding experience. It helped me understand both frontend development and how to present myself better as a developer.

If you’re a beginner, don’t wait — start your own portfolio now! It doesn’t have to be perfect — just authentic.

Thanks for reading! 😊
